conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two objects starting from the same location and moving in the same direction, with a velocity-time graph provided.
In a velocity-time graph, the x-axis represents time, and the y-axis represents velocity. The slope of the graph gives the acceleration.
To know the acceleration at time t1, look at the slope of the graph at that point for both objects A and B.
Object A's curve starts from the origin, peaks at t2, and decreases to zero at t4. Object B's curve starts from zero, increases steadily, and continues beyond t4.
At time t1, object A's velocity is increasing with a positive and increasing slope. Object B's velocity is also increasing but with a less steep slope.
Estimate the slopes at time t1 for both objects to determine acceleration.
For object A at t1, the tangent line's slope is positive and steeper than at time zero.
For object B at t1, the tangent line's slope is positive but less steep than object A's.
Object A has higher acceleration than object B at time t1 based on slope estimation.
They do not have the same acceleration at time t1 because object A's slope is greater.
Consider the area under the curve for displacement, but focus on slope for acceleration.
Consider changes in velocity over small time intervals around t1 to compare accelerations.
